fields.description:
This is more of a Christmastime-induced wish than a requirement. The Crowd API ({{SecurityServerClient}}) uses Arrays pretty much exclusively. When programatically dealing with Crowd objects, it's difficult to do using Arrays.

For example, if I want to add an attribute (or many attributes) to a SOAPEntity, I have to pack the attributes into an Array and worry about sizing the Array, etc. It would be wonderful if SOAPEntity stored Attributes as a Collection so that adding a new attribute would be as simple as {{entity.getAttributes.add(attribute)}}.

I know this would lead to a large amount of changes to the Crowd API. Feel free to WONTFIX this request if that's too much to ask. Just thought I'd throw it out there.
fields.summary: Use Collections API instead of Arrays everywhere

fields.description:
SOAPEntity currently only has a {{getAttributes()}} method which returns an array of SOAPAttributes. A convenience method to return a specified Attribute would be a real benefit. Something like this:

{{public String[] getAttribute(String name)}} _This could throw an AttributeDoesNotExist Exception or something like that._

More from the forum post:
{quote}
While I'm on the subject, there are a few convenience methods in SecurityServerClient regarding attributes, but one seems to be missing: getAttributeFromPrincipal(String principal, String attribute) which returns a single SOAPAttribute or maybe just the String value of that attribute. As it stands, I'm probably going to subclass SSC and add this myself since we have a demand for it.

Alternatively (and probably a better solution) would be to have a getAttribute(String attributeName) method on a SOAPPrincipal (really all SOAPEntitys). Having to iterate through the array returned by getAttributes() is just too cumbersome. I'm not sure if I want to go subclassing SOAPEntity to add this method though, since the casting would be a pain.
{quote}
fields.summary: Convenience methods for Attribute retrieval of SOAPEntitys

fields.description: In the Admin Console, Principals have an Attributes tab to manage Attributes for a particular Principal. Since Groups and Roles also extend SOAPEntity, they can also have attributes. It would be super if the Admin Console had an Attributes tab for both Groups and Roles as well.
fields.summary: Allow management of Attributes for Roles and Groups

fields.description:
According to the Hibernate documentation:

* http://www.hibernate.org/117.html#A13

The default persistence system should not be used. Currently we are using it.

The system should be replaced with the highly configurable c3p0 system.

fields.description:
New users who are transitioning an application to use Crowd need more details on if/how they can associate the history of their existing internal accounts with the new Crowd accounts. This should include a high-level summary for potential buyers to browse and a list of which Atlassian applications do/don't support user renaming.

The options are:

1. Application supports username changes.

Applications:
* FishEye (should link to renaming doco)

Should mention manual username changing and explain that if the target application supports script-based user account editing then may be possible to create a script to pull the usernames from Crowd and rename them on the old application through a username mapping file. 

2. Application doesn't support username changes

Applications:
* JIRA (link to feature request/workarounds)
* Confluence

Options
2A. Usernames can be the same under Crowd
User history is only kept if the usernames are an exact match, so local usernames can be ported to Crowd using http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/2.4+Importing+Principals+and+Groups+into+a+Directory

2B. Different usernames
The user history cannot be transferred as the usernames won't match.
fields.summary: Document migration options for clients with internal user repositories

fields.description:
This will make unit-testing these components much easier:
- Crowd Console
- Demo Application
- OpenID Server
- Acegi Connector

For non-Springified components, use constructor injection via singleton factories.

This organisation will allow custom application developers to use the Crowd client libraries either via externally managed singletons through dependency injection (eg. for applications that use IoC already) or via internally managed singleton factories (eg. for applications that don't use IoC).
fields.summary: Use Spring dependency injection for SecurityServerClient and HttpAuthenticator in Crowd applications

fields.description:
Update and expand the Crowd/FishEye integration docs to include full step-by-step instructions.

In particular, also include new instructions on integration with FishEye 1.4 - specific Crowd integration screen in FishEye. So the Crowd docs will have to have a branch: if you are using FE 1.3 or earlier, do this (the old way); if you are using FE 1.4 or later, do this (the new way).

TO DO AT LAUNCH:
* Unhide new page: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+FishEye+1.3.x+to+talk+to+Crowd
* Unhide new page: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/3.2.10+Integrating+Crowd+with+Atlassian+Crucible
* Copy contents of this page to its parent page:  http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Copy+of+3.2.05+Integrating+Crowd+with+Atlassian+FishEye
Remember to check parent page for recent updates before copying, in case you overwrite anything. Remember to copy the attachments too. Remove the draft page. 
* Renumber this page to 3.2.11: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/3.2.10+Integrating+Crowd+with+a+Custom+Application
* Add Crucible integration page to list of connectors on this page: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/1.1.1+Supported+Applications+and+Directories
fields.summary: Documentation for Crowd/FishEye integration, especially for FishEye 1.4

fields.description:
Just as Confluence and JIRA used to do, when JIVE forums is in the same JVM as Crowd, then tomcat will hang.  This is using 1.2.0.

It seemed to work before I enabled group integration in jive.  ie. just user-based integration worked, but group based it seems to hang.
fields.summary: JIVE forums hangs when in the same JVM

fields.description: It should be possible to edit the group and role members. Maybe something similar to the group management tool in JIRA. Now it requires way too many clicks to e.g. add multiple principals to a group.
fields.summary: Edit members of the group or role

fields.description:
Hi Guys,

Trying to add an Active Directory directory but getting the following error:

Operation failed; nested exception is javax.naming.PartialResultException [Root exception is javax.naming.CommunicationException: Vetwest.com.au:389 [Root exception is java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused]]; nested exception is: org.springframework.ldap.UncategorizedLdapException: Operation failed; nested exception is javax.naming.PartialResultException [Root exception is javax.naming.CommunicationException: Vetwest.com.au:389 [Root exception is java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused]]

Have you seen this before? 
I have attached a screenshot of my settings etc.
fields.summary: Adding "Active Directory" Directory error

fields.description:
When starting a client, or even the Crowd Console (as a WAR file).

We should have the ability to tell the Client or the Console just where the crowd.properties file is.
fields.summary: Allow the crowd.properties file to be passed to a Client application as an environment variable

fields.description: Modification of the external directory settings (eg. enabling SSL on an AD server) doesn't allow easy testing to see if the changes were successful - you have to go to the Principal page and list the users to see if you can still list users.
fields.summary: When modifying an external directory, the Test* buttons should be available to check changes

fields.description:
Currently we cache calls made in atlassian-user and os-user to improve the user manager layer of Atlassian products.

It would make sense to push the caching responsibility down the stack (to the Crowd client layer) so that:
- caching code doens't need to be duplicated
- all applications using the Crowd client can take advantage of the "free" caching
- it allows us to develop an event driven cache in the future to further improve performance of all applications using the Crowd client.
fields.summary: Implement caching on Crowd client layer

fields.description:
Currently, there are two files which need to be edited for tweaking the Crowd client library: {{crowd.properties}} and {{crowd-ehcache.xml}}.

It would be good if there was a single file which users can edit to configure the Crowd client. This could be achieved by rolling in the cache configuration in to the {{crowd.properties}} file or by creating a single XML configuration.

Currently, users are unable to tweak the transport layer configuration, such as:
- Max size of connection pool
- GZip requests
- etc, see http://xfire.codehaus.org/HTTP+Transport for other possible parameters.

They should be configurable via the new properties/XML file.
fields.summary: Single point for Crowd client configuration

fields.description:
I have configured Crowd to set the Cookie domain to the corporate domain name. When I installed the demo on my localhost it din't work. The authentication was performed successfully, but the demo just redirected me back to it's login page. The demo's log file stated:

13:00:24,207 INFO  [STDOUT] 13:00:24,207  INFO atlassian.crowd.integration.http.VerifyTokenFilter: Authentication is not valid, redirecting to: http://localhost:8080/demo

*I traced the problem to processClientCookieDomain(Cookie tokenCookie) in the HttpAuthenticator class.*

If the Crowd server has been configured to use f.i. ".domain.com" as cookie domain, this is used in the cookie. The problem is that my browser uses _localhost_ and it probably ignores the cookie completely. It will definitely not sent the cookie back to localhost when the domain is set to ".domain.com", thus the application will handle the user as not authenticated.

When I removed the ".domain.com" setting from the Crowd configuration, the cookie was created with no domain set and I was able to sign in to the demo application.
fields.summary: Wrong domain name in cookies when running webapp on localhost with SSO-enabled Crowd

fields.description:
Crowd binds to for instance OpenLDAP with a preconfigured username and password, which implies that all use of the same directory configuration has the same rights in the LDAP directory. (This could be worked around by configuring multiple connectors to the same backend with different users, but this would soon be a messy configuration.)

It would be really useful to enable Crowd to use anonymous bind to the LDAP directory with the end users own credentials, thus performing operations that the user has right to do.

For instance: If we only want a few users to be able to add new users to the directory, this can be set in OpenLDAP with ACLs. When I log into Crowd it should be, in my opinion, the LDAP directory that authorizes me to perform write operations.

Storing a root/manager-password for the directory in Crowd is the only way for some directories/backends, but for more flexible backends like OpenLDAP it should not be necessary to do this. One can argue that it increases security if no username/passwords are stored in Crowd at all, and since Crowd is an important component in a security framework this should be supported.
fields.summary: Support for user-specific bind to LDAP

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of 31 October 2013|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

Hi everyone,
 
Thank you for your votes and comments on this improvement request. Whilst this is something we would like to implement some day, it is not at the forefront of our upcoming backlog.
 
We will be focussing on improving the integration of Crowd within our Atlassian suite of products, as well as simplifying and improving the overall user management and a unified administrative experience.
 
If our backlog changes and this improvement request becomes a priority, this ticket will be updated. If you'd like to better understand how we make roadmap decisions, have a read of : https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DEV/Implementation+of+New+Features+Policy
 
Cheers, 
Helen Hung
Atlassian Product Management
{panel}

Currently we are limiting what attributes can be created and updated in LDAP.

This is because we do not know the datatypes that are being worked with, numerical, binary, strings.

A possible solution would be to allow the definition of custom attributes for a given directory, defining the type (storage), name etc.
fields.summary: Support creating and updating of custom attributes on Principal objects in the LDAP connector.

fields.description:
{quote}

We were hoping to use the DENY feature to trump all authorization requests in a case where you have competing levels of authorization.

For example:

There are 2 client spaces (company A and company B). Due to competitive concerns a person can not access the information of both companies simultaneously.

Bob is authorized to view company B presently. Let's assume that Bob then has a requirement to view Company A's information.

The business rule that we'd like to establish is that if an administrator enabled Bob to view company A (in this use case) then he would be automatically be unable to view either accounts.

We want to prevent accidental access to both Company A and B simultaneously.
{quote}
fields.summary: Crowd Integration with Active Directory (DENY functionality)

fields.description:
When running the command {{start_crowd.bat}} from {{atlassian-crowd-1.1.2}}, the database files will be stored in {{atlassian-crowd-1.1.2/databaes}}.

If you then switch to using {{atlassian-crowd-1.1.2/apache-tomcat-5.5.20/bin/catalina.bat}} the database files will then be stored in {{atlassian-crowd-1.1.2/apache-tomcat-5.5.20/bin/database/}}.

The database storage path should be relative to the root folder of the archive in the database folder and not {{apache-tomcat-5.5.20/bin/database/}}.
fields.summary: HSQL context path storage issues when not using start_crowd.bat/sh

fields.description:
Add a page/FAQ highlighting the fact that you should not delete users from Crowd when Crowd is hooked up to JIRA.

Reason: If the deleted user is involved in an issue in JIRA, JIRA does not gracefully handle the fact that the user is missing.

To do:
* Search existing JIRA and Crowd documentation to see if there is already such a note.
* Look for the associated JIRA issue, mentioning JIRA's limitations.
* Add a page/FAQ with a clear name, so that it appears in search results and TOC.
* Add a note/link on this page: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/4.03+Deleting+or+Deactivating+a+Principal
* Add a note/link on this page: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/2.3+Specifying+Directory+Permissions
* Refer to this JIRA doc: http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/usermanagement.html#Deleting+a+User
* IM the link to Justen.
fields.summary: Note: Do not delete users when Crowd is hooked up to JIRA

fields.description:
What we would like to do is to monitor access patterns to our extranet to spot intrusions, intrusion attempts. So far we are goind this by analyzing the logs of our central inbound proxy server and correlating users, source IP domains and other information.
With CROWD we gained a central authetication point that records all authentication requests which is great.

However there are a few things that could be improved:
 * It would be nice if CROWD could write a simple audit trail that just records: username, requesting IP (the IP of the applications user, not the application), application and possibly requested information. Preferably in a format a la common log format so that it can be easily processed.
* We can extract this from the current logs (it is a little bit more complicated, but for this god gave us Perl). However what CROWD does not log is the IP of the reuqesting user. Looking at the SOAP API, this information is never given to CROWD. So I suggest to extend the API. This would also allow (possible) CROWD plugins that can enforce IP ranges.
fields.summary: Support traceability of autehtication request to enable intrustion detection and forensics -> add requesting IP to authenticatePrincipal and add analyzable logs
